fa: شام به زودی آماده خواهد شد، اما ما هنوز وقت داریم برای یک نوشیدنی
en:
1.Dinner will be ready soon, but we still have time for a drink 
 2.Dinner will be ready presently, but we still have time for a drink
desc:
Dinner will be ready soon:
Meaning: Dinner will be ready in a short amount of time.
Tone: Informal and common in everyday speech.
Dinner will be ready presently:
Meaning: Dinner will be ready very shortly.
Tone: Slightly more formal and can sound old-fashioned.
Key Difference:
"Soon" is more casual and flexible.
"Presently" is more formal and suggests it will happen very soon.

desc:
We usually say "on Earth" (no "the") when referring to the planet in a general or figurative sense.

Example: The best pizza on Earth.

"on the Earth" is rare and more scientific, used when distinguishing Earth from other celestial bodies.

Example: Water exists on the Earth and on some moons.

desc: Private equity refers to investment in private companies (not publicly traded on stock exchanges) through the purchase of shares or stakes. Investors provide capital with the expectation of high returns, often by improving the company's performance and eventually selling it at a profit

fa: شرکت ما داره تمرکز می کنه روی M&A برای رشد حضور مارکتش
en: Our company is focusing on M&A (Mergers and acquisitions) to grow its market presence
desc:
Mergers and acquisitions (M&A) refer to the processes of combining companies (mergers) or purchasing one company by another (acquisitions).

Mergers occur when two companies join to form a new entity.
Acquisitions happen when one company buys another, which then becomes part of the buying company.
M&A activities are often used to expand market reach, enhance capabilities, or increase efficiencies

fa: شرکت ما داره کاوش می کنه هم فرصتهای VC برای استارت آپ ها و معاملات PE برای به دست آوردن شرکت های تاسیس شده

desc: VC stands for venture capital. It refers to funding provided to early-stage, high-growth potential startups or small businesses in exchange for equity. Venture capital is typically used to help these companies grow and scale before they become profitable or go public.

desc: Ticket size refers to the amount of money invested in a single deal or transaction. In finance and investment, it indicates the scale of individual investments, such as the size of a venture capital investment or a private equity buyout

Use "company" when referring to any type of business, especially larger or more diverse businesses, like technology companies, manufacturing companies, or retail companies.

Use "firm" when referring to businesses that provide professional services, such as law firms, accounting firms, or consulting firms, typically smaller or partnership-based businesses.

en: What is the most disgusting thing you've seen someone do with no shame?
desc:
In your sentence, "What is the most disgusting thing you've seen someone do with no shame?", the structure involves:

"You've seen": This part uses the present perfect tense and refers to a past action (seeing something happen).

"Someone do": After verbs like "seen," "heard," or "watched," we use the base form of the verb (do) rather than its past tense (did).

Breakdown:
"Seen" (past participle) is already in the past tense.
After "seen," you use the base form of the verb "do," not "did," because "seen" is followed by the base form of the verb.
Example Comparisons:
Correct: "I've seen someone do something" (Base form "do" after "seen").
Incorrect: "I've seen someone did something" (Using "did" here is incorrect because it's the past tense form, which doesn't fit the structure after "seen").

en: The only part of the description that remains is the last one
desc:
A restrictive clause gives essential information needed to understand the sentence. It tells you which specific person or thing you're talking about.

Use "that" for restrictive clauses. Example: "The car that is red is mine." (The clause "that is red" tells you which car.)
A non-restrictive clause adds extra information that isn't essential to understand the sentence.

Use "which" for non-restrictive clauses. Example: "The car, which is red, is mine." (The color is just extra info here.)
In your sentence, "that remains" is essential, so we use "that" instead of "which."

en: Have you ever witnessed a life ruined by a small mistake?
desc:
Let's break it down:

Full version: "Have you ever witnessed a life that was ruined from a small mistake?"
This is a full passive sentence with "was."
Reduced version: "Have you ever witnessed a life ruined from a small mistake?"
Here, "that was" is omitted (which is common in English), and "ruined" works as part of a reduced clause.
So, even though it's passive, you don't need "was" because it's implied and reduced.

en: I urgently need information regarding the delivery date for the Frankfurt Airport construction project
desc:
"Regarding," "on," and "about" all mean concerning or related to but vary in formality:

"Regarding": More formal.
"On": Slightly less formal.
"About": Most casual.

fa: لطفا من رو ببخشید, من یک تماس روی خط دیگه زودتر داشتم

fa: تحویل (کالای) شما خواهد رسید در سایت ساخت در ۲۴ ساعت بعدی
en: Your delivery will arrive at the construction site within the next 24 hours
desc:
The verb "arrive" doesn't always imply that something moves on its own. It's often used to describe when an object reaches a destination, regardless of who or what is physically transporting it.

In this case, "Your delivery will arrive" means that the delivery is expected to reach the site. The sentence focuses on the final result—the delivery being at the construction site—not on who or what actually brings it there.

If you prefer to emphasize the fact that it's being brought by someone, you could rephrase it:

"Your delivery will be delivered to the construction site."

If the subject were plural (e.g., "three quarters of the slices"), you would use "were."

fa: من یک خواهر و برادر (تنی زادگان) دارم
en: I have one sibling
desc:
The difference between "sibling" and "siblings" is:

"Sibling" (singular): Refers to one brother or sister.

Example: I have one sibling.
"Siblings" (plural): Refers to two or more brothers or sisters.

Example: I have three siblings.
So, "sibling" is for one, while "siblings" is for more than one.

 2.You make me blush

desc:
I was just about to leave: Implies that you were on the verge of leaving at that exact moment but hadn't left yet. It suggests immediate intent or action that was about to happen.

 I wanted to leave: Expresses a desire or intention to leave, but doesn't necessarily imply that you were close to doing so. It reflects a wish or plan to leave, which may or may not have been acted upon.

fa: چه چیزی باعث ادرار کف آلود میشود؟

fa: این خط تنظیم میکند یک قانون دید پیشفرض را تا بسازد همه ویژگیها را نامرئی به طور پیشفرض
en: This line sets a default visibility rule to make all properties invisible by default
desc:
When "to" is a preposition (as in "look forward to," "used to," "committed to"), it's followed by a verb in the -ing form.

When "to" is part of an infinitive (like "to go," "to see"), it's followed by the base form of the verb.

fa: این خط لغو می کند دید پیش فرض را برای فیلدها فقط, میسازد همه فیلدها را واجد شرایط برای JSON سریال سازی و سریال زدایی
en: This line overrides the default visibility for fields only, making all fields eligible for JSON serialization and deserialization

fa: او (مرد) هرگز خانواده خود را (فرضی) رها نمی کرد, صرف نظر از شرایط
en: He would never forsake/abandon his family, no matter the circumstances
desc:
Forsake: Often implies a conscious decision to leave something once valued, with a sense of loyalty or commitment being broken. It's commonly used in more emotional or serious contexts. 

Abandon: Typically means leaving something or someone without intent to return, often suddenly or irresponsibly. It's used in both neutral and emotional contexts.

Example: "They had to abandon the project due to lack of funds."

fa: تیم پیروزی خود را جشن می گیرد
en: The team celebrates their victory
desc: In English, it's common to use "their" as a gender-neutral singular pronoun to refer to a collective noun like "team." While "team" is singular, it represents a group of individuals, so "their" is used to indicate possession collectively.

fa: این تیم مصمم بود رقبای خود را شکست دهد (به پایین کشیدن) در بازی قهرمانی
en: The team was determined to take down their rivals in the championship game
desc: In English, when referring to a group (like "team"), we often use "their" instead of "its" because the group consists of multiple people. So, "their" shows possession for the people in the team. In this case, "their rivals" means the rivals of the team.

fa: آیا تا به حال احساس گم شدن کردی وقتی همکارانتان شروع به صحبت انگلیسی با یکدیگر؟
en: Do you ever feel lost when your colleagues start speaking English to each other?
desc:
Did you ever feel – این جمله به یک زمان مشخص در گذشته اشاره دارد. مثل اینکه بپرسیم «آیا در دوران خاصی این حس رو داشتی؟»

Do you ever feel – این حالت به چیزی اشاره دارد که ممکن است همیشه یا به صورت مرتب اتفاق بیفتد، به‌ویژه در زمان حال. یعنی «آیا الآن هم گاهی این حس رو داری؟»

Have you ever felt – این جمله به تجربه‌ای کلی اشاره دارد که از گذشته تا حالا شاید یک بار اتفاق افتاده باشد. مثل اینکه بپرسیم «تا حالا هیچ وقت این حس رو داشتی؟»

So:

Did = تجربه‌ای در گذشته مشخص
Do = تجربه‌ای جاری و مرتب
Have = تجربه‌ای کلی تا به حال

desc:
In the sentence "The water cascaded down the rocks, creating a beautiful waterfall," the word "creating" refers to an ongoing action that happens as a result of the cascading water.

"Creating" is a present participle that describes the effect or result of the cascading action.
The main action is in the past tense ("cascaded"), while "creating" describes what was happening at the same time.

en: I decided to run for Staff Engineer Manager to take on more leadership responsibilities
desc:
Take on is more about accepting or engaging with a new task, challenge, or responsibility. It often implies voluntary engagement with something new rather than inheriting or seizing control. For instance, accepting more work, projects, or challenges falls under "take on."

Take over specifically involves assuming control or responsibility that was previously held by someone else. It often indicates a transition of authority or leadership, such as when one person inherits a position or a company acquires control of another business.

desc:
Hang on: Informal, means wait, grip something, or endure. (Hang on, I'll be back!)

Hold on: Slightly formal, means wait or grip something. (Hold on, this seems wrong.)

Key: "Hang on" feels casual; "Hold on" can sound more serious.

en: He has the ability to bring forth new ideas when they are needed
desc:
Bring forth: Suggests creating or producing something, often with emphasis on originality or making something emerge. (He can generate new ideas when needed.)

Bring up: Suggests introducing or mentioning something in a conversation. (He can mention or propose ideas when needed.)

The first emphasizes creativity; the second focuses on discussion or presentation.

fa: من سعی می کنم از خطر دور باشم

fa: بازخورد شما باقی می ماند ارزشمند (قابل ارزش گذاری نیست) برای ما
en: Your feedback remains invaluable to us
desc:
"Invaluable to us":

"To" indicates the recipient or beneficiary of the value.
It clearly shows that the feedback's value is directed towards and benefits the speaker or their group.
This aligns with the common usage of "invaluable" in this context.
"Invaluable for us":

"For" suggests a purpose or a means to an end. While feedback can be used for a purpose, it doesn't fit the natural flow of this sentence.
It sounds like the feedback is used as a tool, not that it is a value.
It is not the correct idiom.
In short, stick with "your feedback remains invaluable to us."

fa: تفاوت (این) است که CC همه گیرندگان را نشان می دهد، در حالی که BCC آنها را پنهان می کند، از اینرو "کپی کربن کور"
en: The difference is that CC shows all recipients, while BCC hides them, hence "blind carbon copy"
desc: In "carbon copy," the term "carbon" refers to carbon paper, which was historically used to make duplicate copies of written or typed documents. When sending an email, "carbon copy" (CC) is a digital metaphor for sharing a duplicate of the email with others. It doesn't literally involve carbon but symbolizes sending a copy to additional recipients.

fa: او (مرد) کمکم کرد از صمیم قلبش
en: He helped me out of his heart
desc:
"I spoke out of my mind."

This suggests you spoke irrationally, without thinking clearly—almost as if you were not in control of your thoughts.
"Out of" here implies being outside of a normal state (like "out of control" or "out of character").
"He helped me out of his heart."

This means he helped you sincerely, from deep emotions or kindness.
"Out of" here means "because of" (like "out of love" or "out of respect").
So yes, the phrase "out of" has opposite meanings depending on usage—either being outside a state or coming from a reason/motivation.

fa: من شرط می بندم تو آرزو می کردی همین الان از پله ها رفته بودی
en: I bet you wish you'd taken the stairs right about now
desc:
The phrase "right about now" is a common expression in English, meaning "at this very moment" or "around this time," and is the correct idiomatic usage. 


 Use "right about now" for a casual, conversational tone.
Use "right now" for a straightforward or serious tone, but it's less common in this context.

fa: (این) به من کمک کرد غلبه کنم بر تمام ناامنی (که) من داشتم
en: It helped me overcome all the insecurity I had
desc:
"It helped me overcome"

This is more concise and commonly used in everyday speech and writing.

Example: "The support from my friends helped me overcome my fears."

"It helped me to overcome"

This version includes the infinitive marker "to," which can sound a bit more formal or emphasize the action.

Example: "The therapy sessions helped me to overcome my anxiety."

fa: احتمال وقوع آن استثنا کم است
en: The likelihood of that exception happening is low
desc:
In English, when we use the structure "the likelihood of", it’s usually followed by a noun or a gerund (which is the -ing form of a verb acting as a noun). In your sentence, the correct form would be "that exception happening", where "happening" is the gerund.

Why it's wrong:
"Happening that exception" places the gerund "happening" in the wrong order. It should come after the noun (i.e., "that exception").

English tends to have a noun + gerund structure when talking about likelihood, possibility, etc.

desc:
✅ Turned out
= Emphasizes the number of people who came, often for a public event.
🔹 Hundreds of people turned out to see the parade.
→ Suggests a big crowd came, maybe unexpectedly.

✅ Turned up
= Means came or arrived, more neutral or casual.
🔹 Hundreds of people turned up to see the parade.
→ Just states that people came.

fa: من عذرخواهی می کنم برای رفتار دیشبم. من نمی دانم چه بر من غلبه (مستولی) کرده بود
en: I apologise for my behaviour last night. I don't know what came over me

fa: مردی که قرار بود از این کشور محافظت کند به خطرش انداخت بخاطر بی احتیاطی و جوگیری (بی احتیاطی و تصمیم گیری لحظه ای در اثر جو زدگی)
en: The man who was supposed to protect this country put it in danger because of his recklessness and impulsiveness

fa: غذا در آن رستوران کاملاً (مطلقا) فوق العاده (ترسناک) است
en: The food at that restaurant is absolutely terrific

fa: تو درو می کنی چیزی که تو بکاری
en: You reap what you sow

fa: او (زن) در یک رابطه بود و شوهرش بسیار (زیبا) زن ستیز بود
en: She was in a relationship and her husband was pretty misogynistic /میسا جِنیستک/

fa: اشتباه کردن (کار) انسان است
en: To err is human

fa: کوه به طرز سرسام آوری بلند بود
en: The mountain was staggeringly tall
desc:
Strikingly = noticeable
Staggeringly = shocking

fa: طول کشید برام بیش از یک ساعت تا انتخاب کنم لباس عالی را برای مصاحبه شغلیم
en: It took me over an hour to choose the perfect outfit for my job interview

fa: من کامنت کردم لاگ های اشکال زدایی را ، اما بعداً آنها را از کامنت خارج کردم
en: I commented out the debug logs, but later uncommented them

fa: من همیشه این کلمه را اشتباه استفاده می کنم
en: I always misuse this word

fa: من همیشه یکی را به جای دیگری اشتباه می گیرم
en: I always mistake one for the other
desc:
✔️ confuse A and B → natural and modern

✔️ mistake A for B → correct but a different structure

fa: او (مرد) می قاپد فرصت را هر وقت پیش بیاید سر راهش
en: He snatches the opportunity whenever it comes his way

fa: نگران مشاجره نباش, فقط یک طوفان در یک فنجان چای است (این فقط یه توپ تو کوزه است)
en: Don't worry about the argument, it's just a storm in a teacup
desc: A lot of fuss or excitement over something that is not important or doesn't matter much

fa: برایم سخت است که تا دیروقت بیدار بمانم وقتی من مجبورم کار کنم زود روز بعد
en: It's hard for me to stay up late when I have to work early the next day

fa: آنها داشتن تلاش می کردند تا حل کردن (ریش ریش , نخ کش کردن) علت مرگ را
en: They were attempting to unravel the cause of death

fa: ایجاد کن یک برش کوچک پایین دنده ها
en: Make a small incision below the ribs

fa: معرفی نامه ها مهیا نمی کنند هیچ مزیتی در این مورد، زیرا همه کاندیداها می روند از فرآیند یکسانی
en: Referrals don't provide any advantage in this case, as all candidates go through the same process

fa: اگر کاربر به آن گروه تعلق دارد، در نظرش بگیر به عنوان درست; در غیر این صورت، نادرست (false)
en: If the user belongs to that group, consider it as true; otherwise, false

fa: تو گفتی تو جمعه خواهی (فرضی) آمد
en: You said you would come on Friday

fa: معلم گفت ما یک امتحان خواهیم (فرضی) داشت
en: The teacher said we would have an exam

fa: من فکر کردم او (زن) بهم زنگ خواهد زد (فرضی) امروز
en: I thought she would call me today

fa: از من به تو نصیحت (فقط یک نکته برای عاقل), بیار پول نقد
en: Just a word to the wise, bring cash

fa: من (مدتی) فکر می کردم در رابطه چیزی که تو گفتی و با تمام احترامی که قائلم، من فکر می کنم تو اشتباه میکنی
en: I've been thinking about what you said and, with all due respect, I think you're mistaken

fa: به خودم مربوطه
en: It's up to me

fa: من اشتباهم را قبول می کنم (من می ایستم اصلاح شده)
en: I stand corrected

fa: تو مرا غافلگیر کردی
en: You snuck up on me

fa: این یه بی احترامیه (توهین آمیزه)! اونا لغو کردن پرواز ما رو بدون اطلاع!
en: This is an outrage! They canceled our flight without notice!

fa: مسئله (مورد) در حال بررسی است و به محض اینکه (دوباره) حل شد، ما بلافاصله شما را آگاه خواهیم کرد
en: The issue is being addressed, and once it's resolved, we'll notify you right away

fa: من قرار می دهم کتاب را روی میز هر شب. دیروز، من هم آنجا قراردادمش
en: I lay the book on the table every night. Yesterday, I laid it there too

fa: من روی تخت دراز می کشم وقتی من خسته ام. دیروز، من دراز کشیدم آنجا برای ساعت ها
en: I lie on the bed when I'm tired. Yesterday, I lay there for hours

fa: من دارم قرار می دهم کتاب را روی میز همین الان
en: I am laying the book on the table right now

fa: من دارم دراز می کشم روی کاناپه در این لحظه
en: I am lying /لایینگ/ on the couch at the moment
desc: "I am lying down on the couch at the moment" — emphasizes the action of reclining or getting into that position

fa: اقتصاد آمریکا کوچک شد در سه ماه اول سال در بحبوحه عدم قطعیت در مورد (روی) تعرفه ها
en: The American economy shrank in the first three months of the year amid uncertainty over tariffs

fa: کسب و کارها واردات کردن بیشتر جلوتر از عوارض، و مصرف کنندگان خرج کردند کمتر
en: Businesses imported more ahead of the levies, and consumers spent less

fa: من قانع شدم
en: I'm sold

fa: من پشت در آپارتمانم (در قفل شد) ماندم
en: I was locked out of my apartment

fa: من جا ماندم
en: I was left behind

fa: Gradle Wrapper هست یک مکانیزم که اطمینان می دهد یک پروژه ساخته شده است با یک ورژنی از Gradle, صرف نظر از ورژن Gradle نصب شده روی دستگاه توسعه دهنده
en: The Gradle Wrapper is a mechanism to ensure that a project is built with a specific version of Gradle, regardless of the Gradle version installed on the developer's machine

fa: هوا او (زن) را کسل کرد
en: The weather made her lethargic
